title: A.I. Spending Is Accelerating Among Tech’s Biggest Companies
summary: Despite the risk of a bubble, Google, Meta, Microsoft and Amazon plan to spend billions more on artificial intelligence than they already do.

summary: Plus, your Friday news quiz.

title: The Debate Dividing the Supreme Court’s Liberal Justices
summary: Outnumbered and facing vast stakes, Justices Kagan and Jackson are split over the best approach: investing in diplomacy inside the court or sounding the alarm outside.

title: Trump’s Call to Resume Nuclear Testing After Decades Revives a Cold War Debate
summary: President Trump explained the order by saying other, unnamed nations were testing their own nuclear weapons, even though no country has tested since 2017.

title: How the Trump-Xi Meeting Eased a Major Trade War
summary: President Trump and China’s leader Xi Jinping just had a highly anticipated meeting in South Korea. David Pierson, a New York Times foreign correspondent covering China, breaks down what they accomplished and how they de-escalated a major trade war.

title: In China Truce on Tariffs and Rare Earths, National Security Controls Are Bargaining Chip
summary: Some analysts say Beijing won a major victory in its trade talks: Getting the U.S. to withdraw a national security measure that previously was not under discussion.

title: What to Know About US Nuclear Weapons as Trump Threatens to Restart Testing
summary: Though the country’s nuclear arsenal has undergone no explosive testing for decades, federal experts say it can reliably obliterate targets halfway around the globe.

title: Executions and Mass Casualties: Videos Show Horror Unfolding in Sudan
summary: Evidence of atrocities emerging from the city of El Fasher stoked fears that the Sudanese region of Darfur is plunging, once again, into a cycle of genocidal violence.

title: Dissecting Three Stephen King Adaptations
summary: Gilbert Cruz, editor of The New York Times Book Review, breaks down three Stephen King movie adaptations and how they differ from their source material.

title: In Louisiana, Threat of Lost SNAP Food Benefits Is Rattling the Vulnerable
summary: The state has vowed to step in and provide food assistance for many who face a cut-off in federal SNAP aid. But there is still fear and anxiety about how to get by.

summary: President Trump traveled to Asia to be a statesman, a showman and a traveling salesman, depending on the audience.

summary: At an Asia-Pacific summit, the Chinese leader urged countries to “resist unilateral bullying,” an appeal that seemed at odds with his country’s recent actions.

title: Trump Officials Move Into Military Residences in D.C. Area
summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth moved into a home at Fort McNair traditionally reserved for the Army’s vice chief of staff. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and others also now live in military housing.

summary: Zohran Mamdani’s opposition to Israel’s treatment of Palestinians could influence New York City’s investments, his appointees and city policing tactics.

title: Coal Jobs Are Disappearing on the Navajo Nation. Can Trump Bring Them Back?
summary: As the economic engine for the region, coal offered solid work. But it has also used up water, polluted the air and raised health concerns.

summary: But the companies and other large oil producers are continuing to increase production because drilling still remains profitable.

summary: The Texas attorney general has escalated the pace of high-profile legal actions, raising concern that his Senate campaign is influencing his law enforcement work.

summary: The map, which is expected to be approved on Friday morning by the state’s redistricting commission, improves Republicans’ odds of picking up two more seats.

summary: A soccer governing body that both countries have helped bankroll gave them extra rest and home-field advantage to set up World Cup qualification.

summary: Jensen Huang, the Nvidia chief executive, and the leaders of Samsung and Hyundai staged a regular-folks outing in Seoul before announcing a business deal.

title: Patricia Crowther, Who Brought Witchcraft Out of the Shadows, Dies at 97
summary: As a high priestess of Wicca, a branch of modern paganism founded in England, she promoted an image of witches as early feminists who were benevolent and spiritual.
